hints.content: Start by understanding what an alphabetical continuous substring is. It consists of characters that appear consecutively in the English alphabet. For example, 'abc' is continuous, while 'ac' is not.
Consider how you can iterate through the string. You might want to compare each character with the next one to check if they are consecutive in the alphabet.
Remember to keep track of the length of the current continuous substring. You can initialize a variable to count the length as you traverse the string.
When you find two consecutive characters, increment your current length counter. For example, if you are at 'a' and the next character is 'b', you can increase your count.

Think about what to do when you encounter a character that breaks the alphabetical order. You will need to compare the current length with a maximum length variable and reset the current length counter.
Make sure to handle the case where the entire string is a continuous substring, like 'abcde'. You should check and update your maximum length at the end of your loop as well.
Consider edge cases, such as a string with only one character. The length of the longest alphabetical continuous substring in this case should be 1.
Think about how to structure your loop. You can use a simple for loop that goes from the first character to the second-to-last character, comparing each character with the next.
Don't forget to return the maximum length found. After finishing the iteration, ensure that you return the correct value based on the maximum length variable.
As a final step, remember to test your solution with various inputs, including strings with repeated characters and strings that are not continuous at all, to ensure your logic holds.

questionNotes: The input string consists of only lowercase English letters.
Return the length of the longest alphabetical continuous substring.
Consider edge cases like single-character strings.
